FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  69-year-old woman with alcohol abuse, who presents with jaundice
 and elevated bilirubin, unclear if this represents acute on chronic alcoholic
 hepatitis versus other etiology of hepatitis.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  The procedure was performed by Drs. [**First Name (STitle) 1368**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 3014**], and [**Doctor Last Name 167**],
 the attending radiologist, who was present and supervising throughout.

 MEDICATIONS: 1 mg of Versed and 50 micrograms of Fentanyl were administered
 via divided doses for moderate conscious sedation with continuous hemodynamic
 monitoring throught the 45 minute intraservice time ; 1 gram of Ancef was
 admninistered for antibiotic prophylaxis;

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  After written informed consent was obtained from the
 patient explaining the risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure, the
 patient was placed supine on the angiography table, and the right neck was
 prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.  A preprocedure timeout
 was performed.  Local anesthesia was introduced using 1% lidocaine.  Using
 ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured.  A 0.018
 guide wire was advanced through the needle, and the needle was exchanged for a
 4.5 French micropuncture sheath.  The wire and inner dilator were removed, and
 a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire was advanced through the micropuncture sheath into the IVC
 under fluoroscopic guidance.  The micropuncture sheath was then exchanged for
 a 9 French 45 cm [**Last Name (un) 67**] tip sheath.  Using a combination of a 5 F MPA catheter
 and a Glidewire, access was obtained into the right hepatic vein under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  The guide wire was exchanged for a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire,
 and the catheter removed, and a Cook transjugular liver core biopsy set was
 used to perform three passes into the right lobe of the liver, and tissue
 samples were obtained.  The biopsy set was removed and then the catheter and
 vascular sheath, and manual compression was held until hemostasis was
 achieved.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post-
 procedure complications.

 measuring approximately 7.0 x 4.0 x 11.0 cm. A small amount of high- density
 fluid is also present within the pericardium consistent with hemopericardium.

 The ascending aorta is dilated up to 5.0 cm. There are extensive
 atherosclerotic calcifications of the aortic arch with wall irregularity at

 up to a caliber of 3.2 cm.  The iliac arteries also show heavy atherosclerotic

FINAL REPORT
 MEDICAL HISTORY:  73-year-old man with anaplastic thyroid cancer, requiring a
 new right-sided PICC line and removal of an existing left-sided PICC line.

 CLINICIANS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2522**] performed the procedure with Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 7210**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 557**], the
 attending radiologist, present throughout the procedure.

 ANESTHESIA:  Local anesthesia was administered with 1% lidocaine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  A verbal consent was obtained after explaining the
 procedure and risks involved to the patient.  The right upper arm was prepped
 and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  A preprocedure huddle and timeout
 were performed as per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.

 Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial vein was
 punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.  Hard
 copies of ultrasound images obtained before and immediately after establishing
 intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over the guide wire.
 There was difficulty in advancing the micropuncture wire through the right
 subclavian vein.  A venogram was performed using 20 cc of Optiray 60%.  The
 venogram demonstrates marked narrowing of the right subclavian vein with
 extensive venous collateralization.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 0.018
 guide wire was used to traverse the narrowed right subclavian vein.  A 4
 French PICC line measuring 40 cm was successfully positioned in the distal
 SVC.  The position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film
 of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guide wire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.  The patient
 tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate complications.

 Under sterile technique, the existing, non-functioning left-sided PICC line
 was removed.  A sterile dressing was again applied.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: 85-year-old woman with facial surgery unable to take oral intake.
 Placement of percutaneous gastrostomy tube.

 COMPARISON: none.

 CLINICIANS: Dr. [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) 1580**] [**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1581**] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 753**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 754**]. Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 753**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 754**], the
 attending radiologist, was present and supervising throughout.

 ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of a
 total of 50 mcg of fentanyl, while patient's hemodynamic parameters were
 continuously monitored. Local anesthesia was provided with 1% buffered
 lidocaine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:

 An informed written consent was obtained after explaining the procedure,
 benefits, alternatives and risks involved. The patient was brought to the
 angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table. The upper abdomen
 was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure huddle and
 timeout was performed as per [**Hospital1 51**] protocol.

 A scout image of the abdomen was obtained and stored. The stomach was
 insufflated with air through the indwelling nasogastric tube. Under
 fluoroscopy, the outline of the stomach and colon were noted. The liver edge
 was was identified by percussion. Then under fluoroscopic guidance, three
 T-fastener buttons were sequentially deployed elevating the stomach to the
 anterior abdominal wall in a triangular fashion.
 A small skin incision was made between the T-fastener buttons and an 18-gauge
 needle was introduced into the stomach under fluoroscopic guidance. The
 position of the needle was confirmed with small amount of contrast injection.
 The needle was removed over [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 539**] wire and soft tissue tract dilated. Then a
 12 French Wills-[**Doctor Last Name 5929**] G-tube was placed over the wire. Guidewire was removed
 and retaining loop of the catheter was formed in the stomach and locked after
 confirming the position of the catheter by contrast injection.  The catheter
 was flushed, capped and secured to the skin. Sterile dressings were applied.
 The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate
 complications.

                                 FINAL REPORT
 CT ANGIOGRAPHY

 HISTORY:  Status post fall, on Coumadin, with facial injuries including
 fracture into the carotid canal.  Evaluate the carotid arteries.

 TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast imaging of the head.

 FINDINGS:  Since the prior head CT scan of [**4-24**], a new right posterior
 parietal/occipital acute subdural hemorrhage has developed, measuring
 approximately 6 mm in maximal width and approximately 33 mm in length.  The
 hemorrhage causes effacement of the adjacent sulci.  As was mentioned in the
 facial bones CT report, more generalized chronic subdural hygromas appear to
 have mildly evolved since the prior study.  These, as well cause mild cerebral
 sulcal effacement, but there is no shift of normally midline structures or
 overt change in ventricular size appreciated.  At this time, there is also
 subarachnoid hemorrhage subjacent to the right frontal skull fracture as well
 as within the posterior aspect of both sylvian fissures.  A tiny amount of
 possible pneumocephalus is seen in relationship to the falx cerebri.  This
 finding was not seen on the prior study.

 CT ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE UPPER NECK AND HEAD, EXTENDING FROM THE LEVEL OF THE
 HYOID BONE AS FAR CEPHALAD AS THE VERTEX OF THE SKULL:  Multiplanar
 reconstructions as well as volumetric offline processed images were created.

 FINDINGS:  There is no definite sign of compromise of the lumen of the
 internal carotid artery through either carotid canal.  The more distal
 internal carotid arteries are patent.  There are moderate left and milder
 right atherosclerotic calcifications involving the supraclinoid portions of
 the internal carotid arteries.  The vertebrobasilar arterial system appears
 patent.  Using the vascular lumen as an index, no definite signs of a
 dissection are noted, although in this regard, fat saturated MR imaging is
 more sensitive in detecting an intramural hematoma.  No other definite
 additional areas of hemodynamically significant stenosis or aneurysm formation
 are present at this time.

 effusions.  The origins of the left main and right coronary arteries were
 identified in their customary positions.  The diameters of the ascending
 aorta, descending aorta, and main pulmonary artery were normal.  The left
 atrial AP dimension was mildly increased.  The left atrial dimensions in the
 4-chamber view was mildly increased.
 The left ventricular end-diastolic dimension was mildly enlarged.  The left
 ventricular end-diastolic volume index was moderately elevated.  The
 calculated left ventricular ejection fraction was severely depressed at 29%,
 with severe regional and global systolic function.  There was severe global
 hypokinesis/akinesis with relative sparing of the basal and mid portions of
 the inferior and inferolateral walls.  The left ventricular mass was normal.
 The right ventricular end-diastolic volume index was normal.  The calculated
 right ventricular ejection fraction was normal at 51%, with normal regional
 and global systolic function.
 The aortic valve was trileaflet with normal valve area.

 Quantitative Flow
 There was no significant intra-cardiac shunt.  Aortic flow demonstrated no
 significant aortic regurgitation.  There was no significant mitral
 regurgitation.  The right ventricular stroke volume and pulmonic flow
 demonstrated mild pulmonic and tricuspid regurgitation.

 Viability
 There was hyperenhancement of the basal anterior septum, the mid and distal
 portions of the inferoseptal, anteroseptal, anterior, and anterolateral
 segments, and the apex.   The hyperenhancement was transmural, consistent with
 poor (<20%) likelihood of functional recovery after segment revascularization.
  The infarct/LV mass ratio was 0.33.

paragraphs.context:
IMPRESSION:
 1.  Midline catheter placed by the IV team noted to be extravascular and
 therefore was removed.

 2.  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically-guided 5 French double-lumen
 PICC line placement via the left brachial venous approach.  Final internal
 length is 55 cm with the tip of the catheter positioned in SVC.  The line is

qas.question: How is the picc line placed?

answers.text:
A new
 access was obtained into a left brachial vein with a micropuncture set and
 ultrasound images were stored before and after gaining intravenous access.  A
 0.018 guidewire was placed through the micropuncture sheath, but again the
 wire could not be advanced past the level of axilla.  Therefore, a small
 amount of contrast was injected demonstrating patent but tortuous veins at the
 level of axilla.  A 0.035 Glidewire was placed through the micropuncture
 sheath and advanced easily past this level into SVC.  A 5 French Kumpe
 catheter was placed over the Glidewire and the wire exchanged for a 0.018 PICC
 line wire.  The Kumpe catheter was removed and a peel-away sheath was placed
 over the guidewire and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line measuring 55 cm in
 length was placed through the peel-away sheath with the tip positioned in the
 SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.  The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then
 removed.  A fluoroscopic spot chest film was obtained and stored digitally.
 The catheter was secured to skin with a Stat-Lock device and sterile dressings
 were applied

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 MEDICAL HISTORY:  70-year-old man with thyroid and esophageal cancer needing
 chemotherapy.  The patient is known to have difficult venous access and IV
 team could only place a midline catheter as the wire could not be advanced
 centrally.  As the patient needs central access for chemotherapy, a request
 was placed for IR-guided exchange or placement of a new PICC line with tip
 positioned centrally.

 CLINICIANS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 9422**] [**Name (STitle) 90**] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the
 attending radiologist, reviewed the study.

 ANESHTESIA:  Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  A verbal consent was obtained after explaining the
 procedure and risks involved to the patient.  The left upper arm including the
 existing midline catheter was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
 A preprocedure huddle and timeout were performed as per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.

 Initial scout image of the left upper arm was obtained demonstrating a midline
 catheter with tip terminating just distal to the axilla.  Attempts to either
 aspirate blood or to flush through either port of the catheter were
 unsuccessful.  A 0.018 guidewire was placed through one of the ports, but the
 wire could not be advanced past the level of the axilla.  At this stage, a
 small amount of contrast was injected through one of the ports demonstrating
 the catheter to be extravascular.  Therefore, the catheter was removed.  A new
 access was obtained into a left brachial vein with a micropuncture set and
 ultrasound images were stored before and after gaining intravenous access.  A
 0.018 guidewire was placed through the micropuncture sheath, but again the
 wire could not be advanced past the level of axilla.  Therefore, a small
 amount of contrast was injected demonstrating patent but tortuous veins at the
 level of axilla.  A 0.035 Glidewire was placed through the micropuncture
 sheath and advanced easily past this level into SVC.  A 5 French Kumpe
 catheter was placed over the Glidewire and the wire exchanged for a 0.018 PICC
 line wire.  The Kumpe catheter was removed and a peel-away sheath was placed
 over the guidewire and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line measuring 55 cm in
 length was placed through the peel-away sheath with the tip positioned in the
 SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.  The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then
 removed.  A fluoroscopic spot chest film was obtained and stored digitally.
 The catheter was secured to skin with a Stat-Lock device and sterile dressings
 were applied.  Both ports of the catheter were easily aspirated and flushed.
 The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate
 complications.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  70-year-old man with anaplastic thyroid cancer and esophageal
 cancer with dysphagia requiring G-tube placement.

 PHYSICIANS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending radiologist, Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 7210**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 557**]
 attending radiologist.

 PROCEDURE:
 1.  Initial spot fluoroscopic image.
 2.  Removal of existing malpositioned nasogastric tube.
 3.  Placement of a 5 French catheter into the stomach.
 4.  Placement of a 12 French percutaneous Wills-[**Doctor Last Name 7943**] gastrostomy tube and 3
 T-tacks.
 5.  Post-tube placement spot fluoroscopic imaging with contrast injection.

 MEDICATIONS: Moderate sedation was provided with divided doses of 0.5 mg IV
 Versed and 25 mcg IV fentanyl throughout the intraprocedure time, during which
 continuous hemodynamic monitoring was performed.  Additionally, the patient
 received 1 g IV Kefzol prior to the procedure.

 PROCEDURE:  Prior to initiation of the procedure, written informed consent was
 obtained and a preprocedure timeout was performed.  Upon initiation of
 procedure, the patient had excessive coughing and bloody sputum.  Initial
 fluoroscopic spot image was performed demonstrating the nasogastric tube
 malpositioned within the retropharynx.  The nasogastric tube was removed and
 under fluoroscopic guidance, a 5 French glide catheter and guidewire were used
 to position the catheter within the stomach.  This was secured to the nose.
 Next, the abdomen was prepped and draped in sterile manner.  The stomach was
 insufflated with air.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, after local lidocaine
 administration, a needle was advanced into the stomach, and a T-Tack was
 deployed.  Location was confirmed with contrast injection.  Sequentially, two
 additional T-tacks were deployed.  Following this, an 18-gauge needle was used
 to access the stomach, for which an 0.035 J-wire was advanced.  Sequential
 fascial dilatation was performed followed by placement of a 12-French
 Wills-[**Doctor Last Name 7943**] tube.  The pigtail was formed within the stomach.  Contrast
 injection confirmed location.  The T-tacks were secured to the skin with 0
 silk suture.  A dressing was applied.  The patiet tolerated the procedure well
 and left the IR suite in good condition.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT

 RADIOPHARMACEUTICAL DATA:
    20.3 mCi F-18 FDG ([**2121-6-6**]);
 INDICATION:  Large right thyroid mass, FNA cytology demonstrating squamous
 cells, with worsening dysphagia.

 METHODS: Approximately 1 hour after intravenous administration of F-18
 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), noncontrast CT images were obtained for attenuation
 correction and for fusion with emission PET images. [The noncontrast CT images
 are not used to diagnose disease independently of the PET images.]  A series of
 overlapping emission PET images was then obtained. The fasting blood glucose
 level, measured by glucometer before injection of FDG, was 96 mg/dL. The area
 imaged spanned the region from the  orbits to the thighs.

 Computed tomography (CT) images were co-registered and fused with emission PET
 images to assist with the anatomic localization of tracer uptake.  The
 determination of the site of tracer uptake seen on PET data can have important
 implications regarding the significance of that uptake.

 INTERPRETATION:

 HEAD/NECK: A large, lobulated mass with hetergeneous solid and cystic components
 arises from the right thyroid lobe and extends into the superior neck at the
 level of the mandible.  This lesion measures 7.3 cm TV x 5.2 cm AP x 8.2 cm CC,
 with SUVmax of 24.13.   There is severe mass effect on and compression of the
 trachea and esophagus.

 No FDG-avid intracranial lesions are seen in the imaged skull base.

 CHEST:  A long-segment region of circumferential wall thickening up to 1.5 cm is
 present in the mid-to-distal esophagus, with SUVmax of 35.12.  This abnormality
 spans a craniocaudal distance of approximately 9.4 cm, from the level of the
 carina to just above the gastroesophageal junction.

 An upper right paratracheal node measures 1.4 cm, with SUVmax of 17.45.  3-mm
 pulmonary nodule in the anterior right upper lobe is non-FDG-avid.  Thoracic
 aortic and three-vessel coronary artery calcifications are present.

 ABDOMEN/PELVIS:  No FDG-avid lesions are seen in the abdomen and pelvis.  Dense
 calcifications are present in the abdominal aorta and iliac arteries.

 MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No FDG-avid lesions are seen in the bones and soft tissues.

 Physiologic uptake is seen in the brain, myocardium, salivary glands, GI and  GU
 tracts, liver and spleen.

FINAL REPORT
 Please note that this is a redictation. The previous dictation has been lost
 during the process of transcription.

 CLINICAL HISTORY:
 86-year-old male with a subarachnoid hemorrhage along the Sylvian fissures
 bilaterally and small intraventricular hemorrhage in the occipital horns
 bilaterally.

 TECHNIQUE:
 Informed consent was obtained from the patient and the patient's family after
 explaining the risks, indications and alternative management. Risks explained
 included stroke, loss of vision and speech, temporary or permanent, with
 possible treatment with stent and coils if needed.

 The patient was brought to the Interventional Neuroradiology Theater and
 placed on the biplane table in supine position. Both groins were prepped and
 draped in the usual sterile fashion. Access to the right common femoral artery
 was obtained using a 19-gauge single wall needle, under local anesthesia using
 1% lidocaine mixed with sodium bicarbonate and with aseptic precautions.
 Through the needle, a 0.35 [**Last Name (un) 52**] wire was introduced and the needle taken
 out. Over the wire, a 5 Fr vascular sheath was placed and connected to a
 saline infusion (mixed with heparin 500 units in 500 cc of saline) with a
 continuous drip. Through the sheath, a 4 Fr Berenstein catheter was introduced
 and connected to continuous saline infusion (with mixture of 1000 units of
 heparin in 1000 cc of saline).

 The following blood vessels were selectively catherized, and arteriograms were
 performed from these locations: left common carotid artery, left internal
 carotid artery, left subclavian artery, left vertebral artery.

 LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY:
 No significant atherosclerotic disease noted.

 LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:
 There is good opacification of the left proximal and distal left internal
 carotid artery, anterior and middle cerebral artery branches. There is a small
 aneurysm measuring approximately 2.5 mm in diameter with a wide neck and
 appears to arise at the origin of the posterior communicating artery.

 LEFT VERTBRAL ARTERY:
 There is minimal narrowing noted at the origin of the left vertebral artery.
 There is good opacification of the proximal and distal left vertebral artery,
 basilar artery and posterior cerebral arteries on both sides.

 The right internal carotid artery and the right vertebral artery could not be
 catheterized secondary to severe tortuosity of the vessels and the patient's
 breathing. The patient will be brought back for re-angiogram of these vessels
 under general anesthesia.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 FNA OF THE CERVICAL LYMPH NODES

 INDICATION:  73-year-old man with right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy
 concerning for malignancy.

 After risk, benefits, alternatives and procedure were explained to the
 patient, written informed consent was obtained.  A preprocedure timeout was
 performed using three patient identifiers.

 Initial ultrasound imaging showed three lymph nodes in the right side of neck,
 measuring up to 1.8 x 2 cm.  The middle of these was chosen for FNA due to
 size and relative distance from adjacent jugular and carotid vessels.

 The site in the right neck was marked, then prepped with alcohol.

 25-gauge needle was used to perform two passes of the FNA through the lymph
 nodes under direct ultrasound guidance (the first with suction and second
 without suction).  The material from the first pass was evaluated by on-site
 cytology team and was deemed adequate. The second sample was sent in cytolyte,
 as advised by cytology.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  No immediate post-procedure
 complications were noted.

 The attending radiologist, Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2916**] [**Name (STitle) 2917**] was present and supervised the
 whole procedure.

FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
 INDICATION:  63-year-old man with known skull fracture.  Evaluate mid base and
 sinuses.

 COMPARISON:  Head CT from five hours prior.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial CT images of the sinuses and facial bones was performed.
 Coronal, sagittal, and bone window reformations were obtained.

 FINDINGS:  There is an approximately 2 cm wide slightly depressed fracture
 fragment of the anterior table of the frontal sinus along its left side. There
 are two minimally displaced right and left paramidline posterior table
 fracture lines at the level just above the crista galli. There is no
 pneumocephalus. There is no evidence of fracture of the cribriform plate.

 Fractures of the superior orbital rims are seen bilaterally, with minimal
 depression of fragments.

 There may be a nondisplaced fracture of the anterior wall of the right
 maxillary sinus (series 400b, image 61).

 Nondisplaced fractures of the right mandibular ramus and coronoid process are
 noted.  However, the mandible is incompletely evaluated.

 Right nasal bone fracture is present.

 There is occipitalization of C1 and partial fusion of C2 and C3.

 There is a moderate amount of ethmoid sinus and frontal sinus mucosal
 thickening and fluid level. There is a small fluid level within the right
 maxillary sinus and mild mucosal thickening bilaterally.

 There is a small subdural hematoma along the anterior left frontal lobe.

 Bony exostoses of the external auditory canals are noted bilaterally, which
 may be due to chronic cold water exposure.

 COMMENT:  The above findings were discussed with [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3048**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3092**] on [**2140-10-3**]
 at approximately 10:30 am.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Right tibial plateau fracture.

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axial images of the right knee were obtained without
 contrast.  Reconstructed images in the coronal and sagittal planes were
 obtained.

 CT RIGHT KNEE WITHOUT CONTRAST:  There is a comminuted lateral tibial plateau
 fracture with impaction.  The maximal inferior displacement of the impacted
 fragments measures 11 mm.  Cortical disruption extends caudally
 anterolaterally, as well as caudally posterolaterally without displacement.

 The medial tibial plateau is unremarkable.  The articular portion of the
 distal femur appears to be intact.  In the distal femoral diaphysis, there is
 a partially visualized intramedullary rod with two interlocking screws seen.

 Soft tissue windows demonstrate a joint effusion, as well as soft tissue
 swelling about the knee joint.  There are foci of gas seen in the adjacent
 soft tissues adjacent to the distal femur likely related to the patient's
 recent surgery.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  This is an 83-year-old man who was in robust health until
 several months prior.  He began a progressive, devastating, debiliting
 decline. Now, he suffers from multiple medical problems and pontine
 infarctions which have essentially left him near "locked-in".  On
 [**1-6**], the patient underwent MRA which suggested long segmental areas of
 narrowing in the basilar.  The patient has not tolerated long-term
 conservative therapy and angioplasty/stenting is considered. The patient and
 his family participated in a family meeting when all options were discussed
 extensively with the patient and family on Friday of last week and the
 treatment is now attempted this Monday ([**2109-2-11**]).

 PROCEDURE: The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure are
 explained to the patient and his children.  They understand and sign the
 consent form.

 The patient is brought to the neurointerventional suite and placed under
 general anesthesia.  A Swan-Ganz catheter is placed via left subclavian
 approach, radial A line is present.

 The groin is prepped  and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  Using standard
 Seldinger technique a 6 French Arrow sheath was placed in the groin.
 Arteriogram was performed through the dilator and demonstrates an extremely
 tortuous iliac and femoral system.  Ultimately, a sheath exchange is performed
 over an exchange length 038 microwire for a 25 cm 6 French bright tip sheath.
 Utilizing a combination of 5 French Berenstein, 5 French [**Doctor Last Name 1408**] 2, 5 French
 [**Doctor Last Name 1408**] 3 in conjunction with long tapered Terumo glidewire and standard
 Terumo glidewire the following vessels are selected:

 The 5 French Berenstein catheter is used to select the right common carotid
 artery.  The carotid bifurcation is studied in AP and lateral projections
 utilizing road map technique.  There is no significant stenosis.  The catheter
 is placed in the internal carotid artery and the camera centered over the
 head.  Arteriographic assessment in the AP and lateral planes demonstrates
 filling of the posterior cerebral territory, predominantly via leptomeningeal
 collaterals to the posterior cerebral.  There is extensive intracranial
 atherosclerotic disease. Venous drainage is predominantly to the right side.

 Next, [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 1408**] 3 catheter is used to select the left common carotid artery.
 Examination is performed over the head via hand injection utilizing AP and
 lateral films.  Again, seen are areas of atherosclerotic narrowing.  There is
 a large posterior communicator with direct supply to the posterior cerebral on
 this left side.

 Next, the 5 French Berenstein catheter is put into the base of the left
 vertebral artery.  This is studied in the neck in AP and lateral positions.
 Then, the camera was centered in the brain and studied in AP and lateral
 positions.  The left vertebral is an extremely tortuous vessel with a complete
 360 degree turn in its base.  The anterior spinal access is a large access
 arising from this artery with prominent spinal drainage seen on this
 examination.  There is no filling of the basilar on this injection.  The
 distal vertebral flows into the posterior inferior cerebellar. The posterior
 inferior cerebellar supplies anastomosis to the superior cerebellar artery.

 Next, the 5 French Berenstein was placed into the right subclavian.  Injection
 and examination of the right subclavian was done with the blood pressure cuff
 placed on the right arm. The right vertebral is a small vessel that appears to
 terminate in a small PICA.  The basilar was not filled.  As the caliber of the
 vertebral was smaller than the catheter being utilized, it was decided to not
 enter the vertebral.

 The examination is discussed extensively with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 37273**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 15994**] of
 Stroke Neurology.  After extensive discussion, the decision is made to stop at
 this point.

 The long sheath is changed for a short 6 French sheath. The heparin is D/C.
 The sheath will be pulled with the aid of a Syvek patch in the PACU.

FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  30-year-old female, 24 weeks pregnant with TTP, requiring
 placement of temporary triple-lumen pheresis line with VIP port.

 OPERATORS:  Procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 234**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 896**] (fellow).  Dr.
 [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending radiologist, supervised and  reviewed the study.

 ANESTHESIA:  1% local lidocaine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  After the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the
 procedure were explained to the patient, informed consent was obtained. The
 potential risks of radiation in a pregnant patient were also reviewed and
 confirmed with the patient.  She was brought to the angiography suite and
 placed supine on the imaging table.  Her abdomen was shielded and the neck and
 indwelling right pheresis catheter were prepped and draped in the usual
 sterile fashion.  A pre-procedural timeout and huddle were performed per [**Hospital1 184**]
 protocol.  Under ultrasound guidance with hard copy images on file, a
 micropuncture set was used to access the left internal jugular vein and a
 0.018 wire was advanced into the SVC. This was subsequently exchanged for a
 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire. A 12 French x 16 cm pheresis catheter with VIP was selected
 and after sequential fascial dilatation, the catheter was placed over the wire
 with the tip positioned in the distal SVC.  The catheter was secured to the
 skin with 0 silk suture.  The catheter was flushed and aspirated well.  A
 final fluoroscopic spot image demonstrated good position of the catheter and
 no pneumothorax.

 The patient was then placed on a gurney and the indwelling right pheresis
 catheter was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complication.

 indentation on the adjacent brain is seen in both frontal and parietal regions

 enhancement adjacent to the left anterior clinoid is again noted, which was
 better visualized on the head CT, indicating a small meningioma.

 Tiny area of susceptibility related low signal within the left subcortical

 products.

 MRA OF THE HEAD:

 The head MRA demonstrates normal flow signal within the arteries of anterior
 and posterior circulation.

paragraphs.context:
INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female with Pauci immune glomerulonephritis and
 worsening renal function.  Requiring exchange transfusion today.  Potentially
 also requiring hemodialysis.

 OPERATORS:  Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 933**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 22835**], and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 1091**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1092**], attending
 interventional radiologist.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1092**] was present and supervising the
 procedure.

 ANESTEHSIA: Local lidocaine

 PROCEDURE:  After the risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to
 the patient, informed consent was obtained.  The patient was brought to the
 angiography suite and laid in supine position.  The right neck was prepped and
 draped in standard sterile fashion.  A preprocedure timeout and huddle were
 performed.  The patient's right neck was examined with ultrasound,
 demonstrating a patent and compressible right internal jugular vein.  This
 vein was cannulated with a micropuncture needle just above the clavicles. Pre-
 and post-cannulation images were obtained and printed.  A guidewire was
 advanced into the SVC through the needle.  The needle was exchanged for a
 micropuncture sheath.  The inner dilator and wire were removed and exchanged
 for [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 379**] wire, which was extended down into the upper right atrium.  The
 sheath was exchanged for a 14 French dilator. Following dilation, the 15 cm
 triple lumen dialysis/pheresis catheter including VIP port was advanced over
 the wire with tip terminating in the high right atrium. The wire was removed,
 the catheter flushed.  A post- procedure fluoroscopic image of the tip
 confirms the tip location in the high right atrium.  The catheter was secured
 to the skin with 0-0 silk suture and dressed appropriately.  There were no
 immediate complications.

paragraphs.context:
HISTORY:  A 73-year-old male with history of thyroid cancer and dyspnea.

 COMPARISON:  MRI dated [**2121-5-15**], PET/CT [**2121-6-6**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous helical acquisition through the neck was performed with
 intravenous contrast.  Coronal and sagittally reformatted images were created.

 FINDINGS:  There is diffuse increased  soft tissue attenuation within the soft
 tissues of the right neck, located posterior to the right sternocleidomastoid
 muscle, encircling the right carotid artery, which is patent.  The right
 inferior jugular vein is not visualized, likely secondary to thrombosis. There
 is reconstitution of the superior aspect of the internal jugular vein at the
 level of the superior hyoid bone, from the right branches of the external
 jugular vein.  Also noted is a moderate sized hypodense area deep to the
 sternocleidomastoid, which may represent either the thrombosed internal
 jugular vein versus a necrotic lymph node.
 The abnormal area of soft tissue attenuation within the right neck extends
 inferiorly into the superior mediastinum surrounding the innominate artery and
 abutting the right aspect of the left common carotid and subclavian arteries,
 all of which are patent.  It also extends around the trachea. No focal
 enhancement is noted. A stent is identified within the trachea extending from
 the subglottic airway to the superior mediastinum.  Secretions are noted
 within the trachea below the level of the stent.  The esophagus is patulous in
 appearance and appears to have a large diverticulum extending to the right of
 midline (2:80).  Normal appearing thyroid gland is noted on the right. On the
 left, the superior aspect of the thyroid is identified.

 There is medialization of the right vocal cord, causing narrowing of the
 airway at this level. Also noted is enlargement of the right ventricle,
 consistent with right vocal cord paralysis. The abnormal soft tissue
 attenuation extends to the region of the right vocal cord, and tumor invasion
 cannot be excluded.

 The osseous structures are intact.  Multilevel degenerative changes noted
 throughout the cervical spine with partial fusion of vertebral body C5 and C6.
 Well-circumscribed lytic lesions are noted within the C3, C4, vertebral
 bodies. seen on prior PET/CT without evidence of abnormal FDG uptake.  No
 additional suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are identified.  There is a
 mucus retention cyst within the left maxillary sinus.  The lung apices reveal
 minimal emphysematous changes.

 INDICATION:  Status post MVA with CT showing mediastinal hematoma.  Aortogram
 was requested by Trauma Service.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  The risks and benefits were explained to the
 patient's family and consent was obtained.

 The attending Radiologist, Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 134**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 135**], was present during the entire
 procedure.

 The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table and the right groin
 was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  Under 1% Lidocaine local
 anesthesia, the right common femoral artery was accessed with a 19-gauge
 needle and a .035 [**Last Name (un) 414**] wire was advanced into the abdominal aorta through
 the needle.  The needle was exchanged for a 7 French [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Doctor Last Name 4740**] catheter,
 which was advanced over the wire into the ascending aorta with the tip just
 above the aortic valve.  An aortogram was performed in RPO and LPO projections
 respectively with injection of nonionic contrast.  The aortogram demonstrated
 a normal appearing ascending aorta, aortic arch and descending aorta, all
 major branches from the arch, as well as bilateral internal mammary arteries.
 The left common carotid artery has a common origin with brachiocephalic
 artery. There is no evidence of contrast extravasation, irregularity or
 aneurysm. The tip of the left chest tube is abutting the aortic arch. This
 finding was relayed to the ICU resident.  At the end of the procedure, the
 catheter was removed over the wire and hemostasis was achieved with manual
 compression.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well with no complications.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  84-year-old man with emphysema, atrial fibrillation and
 urosepsis.  Requesting placement of PICC for antibiotics.

 OPERATORS:  Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 730**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 501**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 411**] [**Doctor Last Name 412**].

 PROCEDURES:
 1.  Post-pyloric tube placement.
 2.  PICC line placement.

 POST-PYLORIC TUBE PLACEMENT:  The patient was brought to the angiography suite
 and placed supine upon the table.  A scout view of the neck and chest
 demonstrates a Dobbhoff tube terminating in the stomach.  An initial attempt
 was made to place a wire through the Dobbhoff tube, however, given its
 thickness, it could not be exchanged for separate catheters.  As such, the
 Dobbhoff two and wire were removed and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 1213**]-[**Doctor First Name 948**] feeding tube was
 placed via the left naris with internal wire which were easily extended down
 beyond the pylorus, with the tip terminating just prior to the ligament of
 Treitz.  The wire was removed and contrast injected, confirming this location.
 A final fluoroscopic view of the abdomen was obtained.  There were no
 immediate complications.

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT:  The patient's right arm was prepped and draped in
 standard sterile fashion.  A preprocedure timeout and huddle were performed
 per standard [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a double lumen PICC line measuring 39 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its terminating in the cavoatrial
 junction.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film
 of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.
 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  44-year-old male status post short-segment ileal resection following
 blunt abdominal trauma, now with diarrhea and GI bleeding.  CT scan suggested
 focal Crohn's disease at the anastomotic site.  Evaluate for extent of small
 bowel inflammation or other pathology.

 COMPARISON:  CT of the abdomen and pelvis dated [**2155-9-15**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted imaging was performed on a 1.5
 Tesla magnet, including dynamic 3D imaging performed prior to, during, and
 following the uneventful intravenous administration of 0.1 mmol/kg (17 ml) of
 Magnevist intravenous contrast. VoLumen  oral contrast and 1 mg of
 intramuscular glucagon was also administered.

 Multiplanar 2D and 3D reformations and subtraction images were generated and
 evaluated on the workstation.

 FINDINGS:  Anteriorly in the mid-abdomen, at site of prior ileal resection and
 end- to- end anastomosis, there is a short-segment of slightly abnormal small
 bowel. This demonstrates transient saccular dilitation just upstream of the
 anastomotic site, but normal peristalsis on functional imaging.  There is
 equivocal wall thickening and a small focus of equivocal hyperenhancement
 (200:68).  However, there is no significant adjacent mesenteric inflammation
 or edema.

 Of note, the mesentery adjacent to this site does appear somewhat distorted,
 with overall deviation to the right abdomen. Given the mesenteric distortion,
 the possibility of an internal hernia cannot be entirely excluded.

 The remainder of the small bowel is unremarkable.  The large bowel is normal
 in appearance without wall thickening or distention.  There is no fluid
 collection to suggest abscess formation.  Small scattered mesenteric nodes are
 not pathologically enlarged.

 The visualized liver is normal in appearance.  There is no biliary ductal
 dilatation.  The spleen, adrenal glands, kidneys, and pancreas are normal. The
 major mesenteric vessels are widely patent.  The bladder is normal in
 appearance. The visualized marrow signal is normal.

 Multiplanar reformations provided multiple imaging perspectives for the
 dynamic series.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  43-year-old female patient with recurrent ovarian neoplasm.

 TECHNIQUE:  CT imaging of the chest, abdomen and pelvis was performed
 following the administration of oral contrast.  Intravenous contrast was not
 administered due to history of iodine allergy.

 COMPARISON:  Comparison is made to prior CT performed [**2193-1-15**].

 FINDINGS:

 CT THORAX:

 No suspicious pulmonary nodule is seen.  No other pulmonary abnormality is
 identified.  There is no significant mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy.

 CT ABDOMEN:

 No focal abnormality is identified within the liver on this study performed
 without intravenous contrast.  The adrenal glands, pancreas, and spleen appear
 normal.  A small area of accessory splenic tissue is again identified adjacent
 to the pancreatic tail.  There is hydronephrosis of the left kidney and
 dilatation of the left ureter to the level of the pelvic brim, unchanged since
 the previous CT.  A right extrarenal pelvis is again identified.  No focal
 abnormality is seen in the right kidney. Several small mesenteric lymph nodes
 are again identified in the left lower abdomen (series 2, image 81), with
 largest measuring 10 mm x 8 mm diameter in comparison to 13 mm x 11 mm on
 prior scan. Although this study was performed without intravenous contrast,
 apparent narrowing of the celiac artery at its origin from the aorta (series
 2, image 57) may represent stenosis.

 CT PELVIS:

 A colostomy is again identified in the left lower abdominal wall.  The large
 left-sided pelvic mass has decreased in size from 93 mm x 81 mm on CT
 [**2193-1-15**] to 87 mm x 54 mm on current scan.  A loop of small bowel with mural
 thickening and mild luminal dilatation is encased by this mass lesion.  The
 tumor also encases the cecal tip.  There is no significant dilatation of the
 small bowel proximal to the lesion, and contrast is seen to pass into the
 right side of the colon.  A 10 mm x 7-mm left external iliac lymph node
 (series 2, image 111) is unchanged in size since prior CT and CT [**2192-12-23**].

 CT OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:

 A small area of sclerosis most to the acetabulum of the right iliac bone
 (series 2, image 112) is unchanged since prior study.  No suspicious lytic or
 sclerotic lesions are seen in the remainder of the bony skeleton.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Anaplastic thyroid cancer.  Restaging.

 TECHNIQUE:  Continuous axial images through the neck were performed without
 intravenous contrast.  Coronal and sagittal reformatted images were performed.

 COMPARISON:  CT of the neck performed [**2121-9-3**].

 FINDINGS:
 Evaluation of the neck is significantly limited without intravenous contrast.

 The right neck mass posterior to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle is
 ill-defined and not well evaluated given the lack of intravenous contrast.
 The visualized portion of the mass does appear significantly larger compared
 with the study performed [**2121-9-3**].  For comparison purposes, the axial
 dimensions of the mass is measured on image 62 of series 2 on the prior exam
 and compared with image 52 series 3 of the current study.  These axial
 dimensions measure 2.2 cm x 2.2 cm on the previous exam and 3.4 cm x 3.8 cm on
 the current exam.  The gross craniocaudal dimension of the mass has also
 increased, current study (image 40 series 5) measures 5.6 cm, compared with
 the previous study (image 47 series 300B) measuring 3.6 cm.  The surrounding
 neck structures grossly demonstrate increased mass effect as well.  The
 margins of lesion are ill-defined and therefore extent of the lesion cannot be
 determined.  The cervical vessels are not identified (lack of contrast) and
 therefore status is indeterminate.  No fat plane can be identified between the
 soft tissue mass and the esophagus.  Medialization of the right vocal cord is
 again noted as well as enlargement of the right ventricle consistent with
 right vocal cord paralysis. Extension of the mass into this region cannot be
 excluded.

 The tracheal stent is patent.  The lower esophagus is patulous and the
 previously described tracheal diverticulum is not seen on this examination.

 Multilevel degenerative changes of the cervical spine with partial fusion of
 C5 and C6 vertebral bodies.  The well-circumscribed lytic lesions within the
 C3 and C4 vertebral bodies have not changed in appearance.  No new osseous
 lesions are identified.  There is mucosal thickening of multiple left ethmoid
 air cells and minimal thickening of the inferior aspect of the left maxillary
 sinus.  Minimal emphysematous changes are noted within the lung apices.

 STUDY:  CT torso.

 INDICATION:  81-year-old male with mediastinal wound dehiscence and elevated
 white blood cell count, of unknown etiology.  Please evaluate for abscess,
 mediastinitis or abdominal process.

 COMPARISON:  [**2141-12-5**].

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axially acquired images were obtained from the thoracic inlet
 to the symphysis with oral and IV contrast.  Multiplanar reformatted images
 were obtained.

 IV CONTRAST:  130 cc Optiray 350.

 CT CHEST WITH CONTRAST:  There is a small hypoattenuating nodule within the
 right lobe of the thyroid, which is unchanged in appearance. A tracheostomy
 tube is again noted, unchanged in position.  There is vague stranding within
 the mediastinal fat surrounding the tracheostomy tube, however, no focal fluid
 collection is detected.  There is dense calcific atherosclerotic plaque within
 the aortic arch and descending thoracic aorta including the left subclavian
 artery.

 The major airways are patent down to the subsegmental level bilaterally. There
 is again noted to be a large left pleural effusion and stable complete left
 lower lobe collapse.  There may be a loculated component of the left effusion
 and a complex effusion cannot be entirely excluded. A previously noted small
 right pleural effusion has increased to a moderate- size.  There is an
 increased amount of passive atelectasis from the larger right pleural effusion
 in the right lower lobe. In the visualized lung parenchyma, no acute
 infectious process is suspected.

 There is dense three- vessel coronary artery calcification and no appreciable
 pericardial effusion is detected.  A mitral valve replacement is again noted,
 unchanged in position.

 CT ABDOMEN WITH CONTRAST:  The liver, spleen, and pancreas are all
 unremarkable.  New small calcification in the gallbladder suggests interval
 development of small stones. There is stable focal thickening of the left
 adrenal gland. In the upper pole of the right kidney, there is an exophytic
 hypoattenuating lesion which is stable in appearance, most consistent with a
 simple cyst.  The kidneys are otherwise unremarkable. There is no
 hydronephrosis.

 A gastrostomy tube is again noted well seated within the stomach without
 evidence of abnormality.  No free fluid or free air is identified within the
 abdomen. There is dense calcific atherosclerotic plaque throughout the
 abdominal aorta and iliac branches.

 CT PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:  There is stable herniation of colon through the
 right inguinal canal and new herniation of colon at the ostium of the left
 inguinal canal.  The colon is filled with stool without evidence of
 obstruction.  The bladder is collapsed around a Foley catheter.  No free fluid
 or free air is detected within the pelvis.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  There is mild increased overlap of the osseous fragments
 of the sternotomy (2:28) suggesting possible movement at the sternotomy site.
 No focal fluid collections are detected within the tissues surrounding the
 sternotomy site.  There is multilevel degenerative changes within the lumbar
 spine with anterior vertebral body osteophyte formation and decreased
 intervertebral bodies disc space at the L5-S1 level.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL HISTORY:
 History of subarachnoid hemorrhage. The patient had a previous angiogram on
 the previous day. The patient was moving and it was difficult to catheterize
 the right internal and right vertebral arteries at the time. Hence the patient
 was brought back and the present angiogram was performed under general
 anesthesia.

 TECHNIQUE:
 Informed consent was obtained from the patient and the patient's family after
 explaining the risks, indications and alternative management. Risks explained
 included stroke, loss of vision and speech, temporary or permanent, with
 possible treatment with stent and coils if needed.

 The patient was brought to the Interventional Neuroradiology Theater and
 placed on the biplane table in supine position. Both groins were prepped and
 draped in the usual sterile fashion. Access to the right common femoral artery
 was obtained using a 19-gauge single wall needle, under local anesthesia using
 1% lidocaine mixed with sodium bicarbonate and with aseptic precautions.
 Through the needle, a 0.35 [**Last Name (un) 52**] wire was introduced and the needle taken
 out. Over the wire, a 5 Fr vascular sheath was placed and connected to a
 saline infusion (mixed with heparin 500 units in 500 cc of saline) with a
 continuous drip. Through the sheath, a 4 Fr Berenstein catheter was introduced
 and connected to continuous saline infusion (with mixture of 1000 units of
 heparin in 1000 cc of saline).

 The following blood vessels were selectively catherized, and arteriograms were
 performed from these locations: right common carotid artery, right internal
 carotid artery, right vertebral artery.

 Please note that the previous dicatation has been lost in the process of
 transcription. This is a redictation.

 RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY:
 No significant atherosclerotic disease noted.

 RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:
 There is good opacification of the proximal and distal right internal carotid
 artery, anterior and middle cerebral artery branches. There is an irregular
 aneurysm noted arising from the posterior communicating artery and measures
 approximately 10 x 6 x 4 mm in size. This appears to be the source of the
 hemorrhage.

 RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY:
 There is good opacification of the proximal and distal right vertebral artery,
 basilar artery and posterior cerebral artery on both sides. No definite
 aneurysm noted.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION: IV access needed for ABx.
 The procedure was explained to the patient. A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST: Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 596**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 192**], the
 Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right baslic vein
 was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set. Hard
 copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access. A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a  PICC line measuring 41 cm in length was then placed through
 the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under fluoroscopic
 guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film
 of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. The catheter was secured
 to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
 complications.

FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
 MRI SCAN OF THE BRAIN

 HISTORY:  Hypercoagulable state with history of venous sinus thrombosis and
 associated venous infarcts.  Here with Wernicke's aphasia, new left-sided
 infarcts with questionable hemorrhage in that locale.

 TECHNIQUE:  Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted brain imaging.

 COMPARISON STUDY:  [**2114-5-18**] MR scan of the brain reported by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 4114**]
 as showing "diminished visualization of the left transverse sinus which is a
 new finding since [**2107-11-12**].  However, a thin rim of flow signal is
 identified within this region indicating recanalization from a chronic
 thrombosis.  Although signal changes indicate this to be a chronic finding,
 clinical correlation is recommended."

 Diffusion-weighted images are normal.  The present 3T study shows somewhat
 greater visibility of the susceptibility regions, likely representing prior
 hemorrhages, compared to the prior study which was performed [**Company 57802**]. This
 difference in visibility likely is related to the higher field strength of the
 present examination technique, rather than new hemorrhages.

 However, there is definitely more white matter FLAIR hyperintensity seen both
 within the anterior and posterior aspects of the left temporal lobe.  This
 change raises the concern for progression of venous infarction since the prior
 MR study, as opposed to a superimposed inflammatory process.  There is stable,
 minimal right sided bowing of the septum pellucidum, suggesting that these
 regions of T2 hyperintensity have an associated edematous characteristic.

 The left cerebellar hemispheric T2 hyperintensities appear to be relatively
 stable in extent.

 TECHNIQUE:  Three-dimensional time-of-flight imaging with multiplanar
 reconstructions.

 FINDINGS:  No discernable arterial vascular pathology is seen at this time.

 MR VENOGRAPHY

 TECHNIQUE:  Two-dimensional time-of-flight imaging with multiplanar
 reconstructions.

 FINDINGS:  The appearance of the partially obstructed superior sagittal sinus
 and left transverse sinus are essentially unaltered compared to the prior
 study of [**2114-5-7**].

FINAL REPORT
 CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS WITH CONTRAST AND REFORMATIONS [**2109-1-19**].

 INDICATION:  Pneumoperitoneum with increasing right upper quadrant pain.

 TECHNIQUE:  Following administration of 150 cc of Optiray for severe
 debilitation, CT was performed from the lung bases to the pubic symphysis.
 Coronal reformations were created per CT enterography protocol.

 COMPARISON:  CT abdomen and pelvis [**2109-1-16**].

 CT ABDOMEN WITH CONTRAST:  Again, there are small bilateral pleural effusions
 with compressive atelectasis/minor consolidation at the bases, not
 significantly changed.  There is interval decrease in the amount of
 subcutaneous emphysema and pneumoperitoneum.  The percutaneous G tube pigtail
 terminates in the proximal duodenum.  The bowel loops are normal in caliber,
 without evidence of obstruction.  The liver, pancreas, spleen and adrenals are
 normal in appearance.  The gallbladder demonstrates vicarious excretion of IV
 contrast and a single dependent stone, unchanged.  There is no evidence of
 undue distention or wall thickening to suggest acute cholecystitis.  There is
 no change in the multiple renal cysts, the largest on the right measuring 3 x
 2.6 cm and the largest on the left measures 3.8 x 3.8 cm.  There is no
 ascites.  There is marked atherosclerotic disease of the abdominal aorta, with
 eccentric mural thrombus.

 CT PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:  Enteric contrast has reached the rectum.  The
 prostate is markedly enlarged and intrudes upon the posterior inferior wall of

qas.question: How was the procedure of pheresis catheter placement?

answers.text:
The right neck was
 prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure timeout and
 huddle were performed per standard [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.  The patient was placed in
 left semi-lateral decubitus position (LPO-[**Doctor Last Name 14451**]).

 Under son[**Name (NI) 536**] guidance with hard copy images on file, the right internal
 jugular vein was cannulated with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle through which
 a 0.018 wire was advanced into the superior vena cava.  The needle was
 exchanged for a micropuncture sheath.  The inner dilator and wire were removed
 and a short [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  Over the
 wire, sequential dilation was performed up to 14 French and the triple-lumen
 hemodialysis catheter (including VIP port) was advanced over the wire with tip
 terminating in the right atrium.  The wire was removed and the catheter
 aspirated and flushed easily.  A final fluoroscopic image of the chest was
 obtained from this location.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with 0 silk
 suture and capped and dressed appropriately.  There were no immediate
 complications

INDICATION:  30-year-old female pregnant with TTP-HUS and severe preeclampsia
 with low platelet count.  Requiring urgent plasmapheresis.

 OPERATORS:  Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 730**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 501**] (fellow) and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 731**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 63**] (attending).

 ANESTHESIA:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of
 fentanyl (25 cmcg) over the total intra-service time of 20 minutes during
 which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.

 PROCEDURE:  After risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the
 patient, written informed consent was obtained.  The patient was brought to
 the angiography suite and placed supine on the table.  The right neck was
 prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  A pre-procedure timeout and
 huddle were performed per standard [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.  The patient was placed in
 left semi-lateral decubitus position (LPO-[**Doctor Last Name 14451**]).

 Under son[**Name (NI) 536**] guidance with hard copy images on file, the right internal
 jugular vein was cannulated with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle through which
 a 0.018 wire was advanced into the superior vena cava.  The needle was
 exchanged for a micropuncture sheath.  The inner dilator and wire were removed
 and a short [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  Over the
 wire, sequential dilation was performed up to 14 French and the triple-lumen
 hemodialysis catheter (including VIP port) was advanced over the wire with tip
 terminating in the right atrium.  The wire was removed and the catheter
 aspirated and flushed easily.  A final fluoroscopic image of the chest was
 obtained from this location.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with 0 silk
 suture and capped and dressed appropriately.  There were no immediate
 complications.

 CT SCAN OF THE FACIAL BONES

 HISTORY:  Status post fall.  On Coumadin.  Evaluate for fracture or
 retrobulbar hematoma.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial non-contrast imaging of the facial bones with sagittal and
 coronal reconstructions.

 COMPARISON STUDY:  CT scan of the head, dated [**2197-4-24**] reported by Dr.
 [**Last Name (STitle) 1009**] as revealing numerous facial and skull fractures- see his extensive
 report for complete description of the findings.

 FINDINGS:

 The massively comminuted skull fracture is not completely depicted on this
 study as a number of its components lie at the vertex of the calvarium.  The
 principal right frontal fracture appears unchanged in its configuration as
 does the extensively comminuted nasal bone fractures.  There is an extensive
 fracture involving the sphenoid sinus septum, with rotation of the fracture
 fragment present.  There is a probable additional fracture involving the
 basisphenoid, principally to the right of midline.  The right orbital roof
 fracture is well depicted on the coronal images as a "blowout" type.  At this
 time, there is no definite sign of either right orbital emphysema or
 pneumocephalus, aside from a tiny focus of gas near the superior portion of
 the falx cerebri. Nevertheless, the fact that these more extensive gas
 collections seen on the previous scan does raise the concern for communication
 between the orbit and sinuses with the intracranial region. There is a
 crescent-shaped of soft tissue density immediately subjacent to the right
 orbital roof, consistent with an orbital hematocyst. The maximum thickness of
 this abnormality is 6 mm. Transversely, it extends from approximately the
 level of the superior oblique muscle to the area of the lacrimal gland.  There
 is no proptosis. There is a mild degree of right and more moderate left-sided
 periorbital soft tissue swelling noted, particularly on the medial side
 adjoining the nose.  There is partial imaging of the petrous temporal bones,
 and confirmation of the suspected complex fracture of this bone on the left
 side, including the ossicular dislocation involving the incus. There is
 bilateral presumed hemotympanum and considerable opacification of the mastoid
 sinuses, along with marked degrees of opacification of both maxillary sinuses,
 likely with hemorrhagic contents.  The sphenoid sinus is essentially totally
 opacified and there are bilateral air-fluid levels and substantial
 opacification of both ethmoid sinuses.  Moderate mucosal thickening and a
 probable air-fluid level is noted within the frontal sinus.  While the present
 study is not optimized for brain tissue detail, there is probably evidence for
 right frontal subarachnoid blood, but no epidural hematoma.  Over the 24 hours
 between scans, there is development of what appear to be bilateral subdural
 hygromas, somewhat more prominent on the patient's left side.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 MEDICAL HISTORY:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female with hypertension admitted with acute
 renal failure secondary to hydralazine-induced glomerulonephritis.  A request
 was made for conversion of a right internal jugular temporary pheresis
 catheter to a tunneled HD catheter.

 CLINICIANS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1090**] [**Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 713**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 714**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 714**] is the attending
 radiologist who supervised the procedure.

 ANESTHESIA:  Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine with epinephrine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  A consent was obtained from patient's daughter after
 explaining the procedure and complications.  Patient was brought to the
 angiography suite, intubated, and sedated.  Patient was placed supine on the
 angiography table and right side of neck as well as existing catheter prepped
 and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was
 performed.  An initial scout radiograph demonstrated appropriate position of
 the existing line.  After appropriate measurements were made, a subcutaneous
 tunnel was created from right anterior chest wall to the skin entry site of
 the existing catheter.  A 14 French AngioDynamics catheter measuring 19 cm
 tip-to-cuff is pulled through the tunnel, exiting at site of the pre-existing
 catheter.  Both ports of the original catheter were aspirated and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 379**] wire
 was advanced through one of the ports into the IVC.  The existing line was
 then removed over the [**Doctor Last Name 379**] wire and a peel-away sheath advanced over the wire
 under fluoroscopic guidance.  The [**Doctor Last Name 379**] wire and inner dilator were then
 removed.  The double-lumen HD catheter was then advanced through the peel-away
 sheath and the sheath removed.  Post-procedural chest x-ray demonstrated
 appropriate positioning of the dialysis catheter with tip positioned in the
 right atrium.  Both ports aspirated and flushed easily.  The skin incision
 over the venopuncture site closed with 4-0 Vicryl and the catheter anchored to
 the skin with 0-silk sutures.  Sterile dressings were applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well without any immediate complications.

 CT CHEST WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  Subcutaneous gas tracks along the lateral and

 few small foci of gas attenuation are seen within the left and right upper
 peritoneal cavity.  A small collection of gas is seen under the left lobe of
 the liver.  High attenuation with the gallbladder likely represents vicarious
 excretion of previously administered IV contrast.  The liver, pancreas,
 spleen, and adrenal glands are normal in appearance.  Several round low
 attenuation structures within the kidneys are likely simple cysts.

 subcutaneous gas attenuation within the tissues of the left thigh extensor and

FINAL REPORT
 CT CHEST

 REASON FOR EXAM:  Evaluate for interstitial lung disease, patient with
 pulmonary hypertension.

 Comparison is made with prior chest x-rays dated [**6-29**] through [**2176-7-3**].

 TECHNIQUE:  High-resolution CT through the chest was performed without IV
 contrast.  Images were acquired in end inspiration and expiration prone and
 supine position.  5, 1.25-mm collimation images and coronal reformations were
 reviewed.

 FINDINGS:  The airways are patent to the subsegmental levels.  Multifocal
 areas of ground-glass opacity in the upper lobes are greater in the right
 side.  The size of the pulmonary arteries that goes towards the area of
 ground-glass opacities have the same caliber as the ones going to the
 non-affected lung.  Subpleural interstitial abnormality in the left upper lobe
 has the appearance of post-radiation changes.

 A tiny calcified granuloma is in the right upper lobe (series 104A, 71).  A
 2-mm nodule in the right upper lobe (5, 25) is not calcified.  Tiny calcified
 granuloma is in the left lower lobe (5, 30).  There is no pleural or
 pericardial effusion.  Cardiac size is normal.  Moderate calcifications are in
 the left circumflex, LAD, main left coronary, and right main coronary artery.
 Mild calcification is in the aortic annulus.  There is no mediastinal, hilar
 or axillary lymphadenopathy.  The main pulmonary arteries are mildly enlarged.
 The right main pulmonary artery measures 30.5 mm.

 Healing fracture is in the lateral aspect of sixth left rib.  Irregularity in
 the distal aspect of the right scapula could represent an old healed fracture
 or a prominent nutrient foramen.  There are no bone findings of malignancy.

 In the upper abdomen there is mild splenomegaly, the liver has nodular
 contours and is mildly shrunken.  The aorta is moderately calcified.
 Calcification is seen in the ostium of the right renal artery.

 and transverse components with evidence of lateral displacement and disruption
 of the left ossicular chain; the fracture component appears to reach the
 labyrinth, with resultant pneumolabyrinth.  There may also be associated
 injury to the seventh nerve complex (not well-assessed on this study).
 5.  Extensive fractures of the sphenoid bone and sphenoid sinus walls with
 completely opacified sphenoid and blood-fluid levels in bilateral maxillary
 sinuses.
 6.  Extensively comminuted "smash" type fracture of the nose.
 7.  No definite involvement of the occipital condyles, jugular foramina,
 carotid or hypoglossal canals (please see separate report of the CT of the
 cervical spine).

 skull base to the vertex and viewed in brain, bone, and lung window on the
 workstation.

 FINDINGS:  There are no comparison studies on record.  There is a severe acute
 soft tissue injury with large right frontal and left parietovertex soft tissue
 swelling, subgaleal hematomas and extensive laceration with subcutaneous
 emphysema.  This is associated with an extensive, circumferential oblique-
 coronal skull fracture which traverses the right frontal and left temporal
 bones, as well as the sphenoid bone and clivus, described in more detail
 below.  The right frontal fracture is associated with a focal lentiform extra-
 axial hematoma measuring roughly 8 mm in thickness and 3.5 cm in maximal
 transverse dimension.  This demonstrates a relatively low-attenuation portion,
 anteriorly, which may represent acute, non-clotted blood.  This collection may
 be bounded by the coronal suture, and therefore lie in the epidural space.
 There is moderate subarachnoid hemorrhage occupying the immediately subjacent
 sulci, which are slightly flattened, due to the mass effect of the hematoma.
 No definite adjacent parenchymal contusion is seen, and there is no associated
 shift of the midline structures or mass effect upon the ipsilateral lateral
 ventricle. There is no evidence of subfalcine, uncal or downward
 transtentorial herniation.  No significant extra-axial hematoma is identified
 at the corresponding left frontotemporal fracture site, though there is
 subarachnoid hemorrhage in the sulci in this region, and there may be a small
 parenchymal contusion, at the level of the left sylvian fissure.

 There is extensive left supra- and periorbital soft tissue edema and
 hemorrhage, which does not appear to violate the orbital cone, and the
 retrobulbar fat in both orbits, as well as the periorbita, is preserved,
 though there is a small amount of right intraorbital emphysema, subjacent to
 an oblique fracture through that orbital roof.  There is extensive acute
 hemorrhage within the nasal cavity and sphenoid sinus, bilaterally, with a
 blood-fluid level within the left maxillary antrum.  Review of bone window
 images demonstrates extensive comminution of the vertex skull fracture, with
 one dominant component continuing in an oblique coronal plane and traversing
 the lateral wall and medial aspect of the right orbit, exiting through the
 ipsilateral anterior clinoid process, as well as the sphenoid sinus and the
 basisphenoid portion of the clivus.  Note that though there is opacification
 of the right mastoid air cells and small fluid level within the ipsilateral
 middle ear cavity, no definite right temporal bone fracture is identified (on
 these 2.5 mm sections).

 The dominant fracture component traversing the left frontal extending into the
 temporal bone continues as a longitudinal fracture involving the mastoid
 portion of the left temporal bone which, again, is largely fluid-filled with
 fluid in the aditus ad antrum.  The relatively thick sections suggest some
 degree of dissociation as well as lateral displacement of the ossicular chain,
 related to the longitudinal fracture.  Additionally, there is a suggestion of
 an oblique-transverse component, extending medially, which transverses the
 bony vestibule, with the appearance of pneumolabyrinth. Though there is
 extensive pneumocephalus as well as apparent dural venous gas bubbles, likely
 related to the series of fractures, described above, there is no definite
 fracture line traversing the occipital condyles, jugular foramina or
 hypoglossal or carotid canals, on these sections.

 Also noted is extensive "smash" fracture involving the nose with extensively
 comminuted, overriding fractures of both nasal bones, likely involving the
 bony nasal septum and, probably, the maxillary spine of the nose.

 COMMENT:  Findings were discussed with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 18477**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2455**] (Trauma SICU) at the
 immediate conclusion of the examination, and recommendation for dedicated
 temporal bone CT was made.

paragraphs.context:
CLINICAL INFORMATION:  The patient is an 80-year-old woman with cardiogenic
 shock from acute MR, with pacemaker in place.  A request was made to place a
 temporary hemodialysis catheter with VIP port.

 OPERATORS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3013**] [**Name (STitle) 3014**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 360**] [**Name (STitle) 65**], the attending radiologist,
 who was present and supervised during whole procedure.

 PROCEDURE:  Placement of temporary hemodialysis catheter.

 ANESTHESIA:  Lidocaine was used for local anesthesia.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  After risks and benefits of the procedure as well as
 local anesthesia were explained, informed consent was obtained.  The patient
 was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table.
 The left side of the neck was prepared and draped in the usual sterile
 fashion.  The left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture
 needle under fluoroscopic guidance.  Hard copies of the ultrasound were
 stored.  A 0.018 wire was then placed through the needle into the SVC using
 flouroscopic guidance. A small incision was made over the needle and the
 needle was removed and replaced with a 4.5 French micropuncture sheath.  The
 wire and the inner 3 French sheath were removed and replaced with a 0.035
 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire with the tip of the [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire terminated in the IVC.  The 4.5
 French sheath was then removed over the wire and a 12 French dilator was
 placed over the wire to dilate the soft tissue tract into the left IJ.  The
 dilator was then removed. A 12 French triple lumen 20-cm temporary
 hemodialysis catheter with a VIP port was then placed over the wire into the
 left IJ with the tip eventually terminated in the right atrium.  All three
 ports of the catheter were aspirated and flushed easily.  The ports were
 capped.  The catheter was sutured to the skin and a sterile dressing was
 applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well, and there were no immediate
 complications.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Inferior ST elevation MI complicated by ATN and acute renal failure.
 The patient has been on CVVH then temporary hemodialysis with need for more
 permanent access.  Request for conversion of the temporary line to a tunneled
 line.

 Comparison is made to prior examination of [**2154-3-18**].

 OPERATORS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 255**], Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 17**], and Dr.
 [**Last Name (STitle) 65**], the attending radiologist, was present and supervised the entire
 procedure.

 PROCEDURE:  Successful conversion of prior temporary dialysis line to left-
 sided 15.5 French 23 cm cuff-to-tip dual-lumen dialysis catheter.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient and
 the [**Hospital 353**] healthcare proxy via telephone.  A preprocedure timeout was
 performed documenting the nature of procedure and the patient identity.  The
 patient was placed supine on the angiographic table and the indwelling left
 neck/left dialysis catheter was prepped and draped in normal sterile fashion.
 Initial scout radiograph demonstrated appropriate positioning of the line.
 First, attention was made towards creation of a tract.  Appropriate
 measurements were made and the subcutaneous tissues were anesthetized with
 epinephrine buffered lidocaine.  A small incision was made and the dialysis
 catheter was tunneled through the left chest wall subcutaneous tissue. The
 indwelling catheter was then aspirated removing all heparin and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 66**] wire
 was advanced through the indwelling lumen into the IVC.  The previously placed
 line was then removed over a wire and a 16 French sheath/dilator device was
 advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the SVC.  The indwelling [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire
 and dilator device were then removed and the dual-lumen dialysis catheter was
 advanced through the peel-away sheath.  Post-procedural radiograph
 demonstrated appropriate positioning of the dialysis catheter with the tip in
 the right atrium.  The skin [**Doctor Last Name 695**] near the jugular access entry point was
 closed with 2-0 Vicryl and the catheter was secured with 0 silk. Sterile
 dressings were applied.  The patient tolerated the procedure well with no
 immediate post-procedure complications.

 Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of 50 mcg of
 fentanyl throughout the total intraservice time of 45 minutes during which the
 patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.
