paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  83 year old male status post pontine infarction. A gastrostomy
 tube was placed percutaneously approximately one month ago. Please replace by
 a gastrojejunostomy tube for aspiration prophyllaxis.

 RADIOLOGISTS: Drs. [**First Name (STitle) 737**] [**Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (LF) 325**], [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2742**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 4496**], and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**]
 [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name (STitle) 325**], Staff Radiologist, was present throughout the
 procedure.

 CONTRAST/MEDICATIONS:  20 ml of Optiray 320 at 60%, in stomach and [**Last Name (un) **]. IV
 conscious sedation with divided doses (total 1 mg) of Versed intravenously
 under continuous hemodynamic monitoring.

 PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS: The procedure was described to the patient's
 next of [**Doctor First Name **] and informed consent obtained. The previously-placed 14-French
 pigtail catheter, with the tip in the gastric antrum, was removed over a 0.035
 Super Stiff Amplatz wire, and a 5-French sheath was then passed over the wire
 such that its distal tip was in the antrum of the stomach. A 5-French multi-
 side-hole catheter was then advanced over the wire, and the wire was exchanged
 for a 0.035 angled Glidewire. With the image intensifier in a steep left
 anterior oblique plane, several attempts were made to pass through the post-
 pyloric region using the Glidewire and with the aid of the catheter, but were
 unsuccessful. The catheter was then exchanged for a 5-French [**Doctor Last Name 1408**] II
 catheter, again unsuccessfully. A 5-French [**Location (un) 4398**] catheter was then used in
 conjunction with the angled Glidewire, and were both manipulated well into the
 jejunum beyond the ligament of Treitz. The wire was then removed, and replaced
 with the 0.035 Amplatz Super Stiff wire. Both the catheter and 5-French sheath
 were then removed, and a 14-French peel-away sheath was advanced over the
 Amplatz Super Stiff wire into the post-pyloric region. A 14-French [**Doctor Last Name 2583**]
 gastrojejunostomy catheter was then placed through the peel-away sheath
 following removal of the inner dilator. The sheath was simultaneously removed.
 The pigtail mechanism was then formed in the third portion of the duodenum,
 and the tip placed well into the jejunum. A gastrojejunostogram was then
 performed, and radiographic images were obtained. The final images demonstrate
 the locking loop mechanism to be projecting over the third portion of the
 duodenum, with the tip of the catheter well into the jejunum beyond the
 ligament of Treitz. There is contrast material visualized in the body of the
 stomach and no extravasation. The catheter was then sutured to the patient's
 skin using 0 Prolene suture material. A Flexi-Track dressing was applied, and
 sterile gauze applied over the entry site.

 COMPLICATIONS:  None.

 alternatives of the procedure, informed written consent was obtained.  A
 timeout procedure was performed utilizing three patient identifiers.  Limited
 ultrasound of the right neck was performed for localization purposes.  The
 skin was cleansed with alcohol solution, and 1% buffered lidocaine was used
 for local anesthetic.  Under direct ultrasound guidance, a 22-gauge spinal
 needle was advanced into the cystic portion of the right thyroid nodule, and
 approximately 3 cc of fluid was removed.  Further cyst aspiration was
 difficult due to the complex nature of the cyst.  Subsequently, fine needle
 aspiration x3 was performed of the more nodular superficial components
 utilizing a 27-gauge needle.  The patient tolerated the procedure well, with
 no immediate complications.  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 2813**] was present for the entire procedure.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  66-year-old woman with CLL, recent viral pneumonia with new
 pulmonary nodule.

 COMPARISONS:  CT chest without contrast from [**2170-7-17**], CT torso with
 contrast from [**2170-6-28**].

 administration of intravenous contrast material and 5 and 1.25 mm axial slices
 coronal and sagittal reformats were completed.

 FINDINGS:  Thyroid gland is unremarkable.  There are no pathologically
 enlarged supraclavicular, axillary or mediastinal lymph nodes.  Small sub-5-mm
 mediastinal lymph nodes are present and similar in size and distribution to
 the prior study.  There are mild coronary artery calcifications.  Small
 pericardial effusion has slightly increased since the prior study which in an
 immunocompromised setting could be suggestive of pericarditis.  The airways
 are patent to the subsegmental levels.

 LUNGS:  Since the recent prior study, there has been significant improvement
 in multiple ground-glass opacities predominantly in the right upper lobe with
 only minimal ground-glass opacities persisting.  The nodule seen in the right
 lower lobe on the prior study measuring 6 mm is no longer identified on this
 exam.  However, there are multiple new nodules with surrounding halos since
 the prior study.  For example, 5-mm right lower lobe nodule (4:174), 3-mm left
 lower lobe nodule (4:144), 2 mm left lower lobe nodule (4:134), 4 mm lingular
 nodule (4:116) are new. In immunocompromise host, the new nodules with
 surrounding halos are concerning for fungal infection.  However, if patient is
 not immunocompromised, differential includes viral infection, new bacterial
 infection, COP or less likely vasculitis.  There is no definite focal
 consolidation or pleural effusion.

 This study is not tailored for evaluation of the subdiaphragmatic structures
 but shows multiple calcifications in the spleen, unchanged from prior exam.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  Since the recent prior study from [**2170-7-17**] prior
 study, there is new slight wedging of the superior endplate of L2.  Since the
 CT torso from [**2170-6-28**], there is also new deformity of the superior
 endplate of T11.  There are no other concerning lytic or sclerotic lesions.

 CLINICAL INDICATION: 75 year old male with intracranial hemorrhage after a
 fall and findings on a prior noncontrast CT scan concerning for an aneurysm or
 mass.

 TECHNIQUE: Axial imaging of the brain without IV contrast enhancement,
 followed by helical CT imaging of the major intracranial arteries during rapid
 infusion of 100 cc of Optiray.  Subsequent delayed contrast enhanced images of
 the brain were obtained.

 CT BRAIN W/O IV CONTRAST:  The patient's known bilateral mixed density
 subdural collections are again noted.  These appear unchanged in size and
 extent in the interval.  There is persistent flattening of the adjacent
 cerebral gyri as well as narrowing of the lateral ventricles.  The basal
 cisterns are not effaced.  The [**Doctor Last Name 181**]-white matter differentiation is preserved.
 The previously described 15 x 8 mm hyperdense focus along the left anterior
 clinoid and the suprasellar space appears unchannged.  There are probable
 punctate calcifications within it.  Differential considerations include
 aneurysm or dense mass.

 CTA OF INTRACRANIAL CIRCULATION: The above described hyperdense focus adjacent
 to the left anterior clinoid and suprasellar space does not demonstrate any
 evidence of enhancement during the arterial bolus.  Additionally, there is
 rightward displacement of the supraclinoid portion of the left internal
 carotid artery as well as posterior displacement of the M1 segment of the left
 MCA, indicating an element of mass effect.  However, both of these vessels
 appear to be intact.   There is no evidence of aneurysmal dilatation.  The
 visualized intracranial arterial circulation is otherwise normal.

 DELAYED CONTRAST ENHANCED CT IMAGES OF THE BRAIN: The previously described
 hyperdensity corresponds to a lobular mass abutting the left anterior clinoid
 and adjacent suprasellar space.  This lesion demonstrates modest contrast
 enhancement and contains punctate calcifications within it.  The most likely
 differential consideration in this location given these characteristics is a
 meningioma.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:
 83-year-old male with left pontine infarction with dense right hemiplegia.
 Long-term feeding required.

 RADIOLOGISTS:
 Drs. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 737**] [**Doctor Last Name **] [**Doctor Last Name 325**], and [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2091**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 27**]. Drs.
 [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name5 (PTitle) 325**] and [**Doctor Last Name 27**] were present throughout procedure.

 CONTRAST/MEDICATIONS:
 20 ml of Optiray 320 at 60%. 100 mcg of Fentanyl and 1 mg Versed were given
 intravenously in divided doses under continued hemodynamic monitoring for
 conscious sedation.

 PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS:
 The procedure was described and informed consent obtained. The stomach was
 insufflated with air, and point of entry into the body of stomach was marked.
 Following local anesthetic infiltration, a 19 gauge spinal needle was inserted
 under fluoroscopic guidance until tenting of the stomach wall was noticed. The
 lumen of the stomach was then entered, and a flush of air was noted through
 the spinal needle. At this time, a 0.035 Bentson guidewire was placed through
 the needle into the lumen of the stomach, and the needle was removed. The
 tract was then dilated using 6, 8, 10, 12, and 14 French dilators under
 fluoroscopic guidance. A small amount of contrast material was injected during
 the course of dilatation which again demonstrated gastric location. The tract
 was continually dilated up to 18 French, and a 16 French MIC gastrostomy tube
 was advanced over a stiff guidewire. At this time, contrast was injected
 through the tube and demonstrated its tip to be still in the stomach. A
 significant amount of previously injected contrast material was noted in a
 large hiatal hernia projecting above the left hemidiaphragm. With the
 guidewire projecting over the body and fundus of the stomach, the securing
 balloon of the MIC gastrostomy tube was inflated with contrast material and
 normal saline, and was noticed to project outside the body of the stomach. The
 tube was deflated, the wire removed, and contrast material was then injected
 directly through the gastrostomy tube, which demonstrated a peritoneal
 location.

 The stomach was reinsufflated with air, and two T-fasteners were placed
 through the wall of the stomach and secured to the anterior abdominal wall. A
 19 gauge needle was then used to access the stomach in an adjacent separate
 puncture site over the anterior abdominal wall. An 0.035 wire was placed
 through the needle, the needle removed, the tract dilated to 7 French. A 7
 French sheath was then placed over the needle, and access into the gastric
 antrum was obtained. A 5 French multipurpose catheter was advanced over the
 guidewire, and the guidewire was exchanged for an angled glidewire. Following
 several technical manipulations, the guidewire was passed through the first
 portion of the duodenum and eventually beyond the ligament of Treitz. The
 multipurpose catheter was advanced over the guidewire, and the glidewire was
 exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff guidewire. The multipurpose catheter and
 7-French sheath were removed, and a 14 French dilator/peelaway sheath was then
 advanced over the Superstiff guidewire into the duodenum. The inner dilator
 was removed, and a 14 French [**Doctor Last Name 2583**] gastrojejunstomy catheter was placed
 through the peelaway sheath. With continued advancement of the catheter
 through the proximal duodenum, the guidewire in the ligament of Treitz
 retracted. This in part was due to the lack of flexibility in the
 gastroduodenal region, secondary to the presence of a large hiatal hernia. At
 this time, a T-fastener placed previously was noted to have dislodged during
 advancement of the catheter and peelaway sheath. At this time, four new T-
 fasteners were placed under fluoroscopic guidance under continued gas
 insufflation via the NG tube. Access was again gained to the body of the
 stomach, and a 14 French pigtail catheter was placed fluoroscopic guidance,
 such that the pigtail formed in the antrum of the stomach. The catheter was
 secured to the patient's skin using 0 Prolene suture material and Flexitrak
 dressing.

 COMPLICATIONS:
 Free air was noted under the hemidiaphragms during and following the
 procedure. The possibility of gastric versus duodenal perforation was a
 concern, and a CT scan of the abdomen was arranged for the following day.

FINAL REPORT
 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION:  IV access needed for IV fluids.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 64**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**],
 the Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a double lumen PICC line measuring 39 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guide wire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

 cerebral artery at its P2 segment.  Stable partial thromboses of the left
 transverse and sigmoid sinuses as well as left internal jugular vein. Near-
 complete thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus.  Partial thrombosis of the
 right internal cerebral vein and basal vein of [**Doctor Last Name 4323**] while their
 counterparts on the left are probably patent."

 similar pattern of abnormal FLAIR signal within the white matter of both
 cerebral hemispheres.  Some of these areas continue to have hemosiderin
 residua and have been considered the remnant of prior venous infarcts.  There
 are no areas of abnormal signal on the diffusion-weighted scans to raise the
 question of an evolving arterial infarct.  It should be mentioned that this

 extensive thrombosis of multiple major venous sinuses, described in detail in

 recanalization. The presence of occlusion of the right basal vein of

 leukocytosis.  Three failed lumbar punctures by MICU resident, attending, and

 indications, and alternatives.

 present and supervising throughout.

 ANESTHESIA:  Local anesthesia was provided with injection of 1% lidocaine to
 the posterior soft tissues overlying the spinal access point.  No IV sedation
 or pain medication was administered, per the request of the primary team.
 However, due to extreme patient discomfort, a total of 50 mcg fentanyl and 1
 mg Versed was administered following the procedure.

 The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed on the
 fluoroscopic table in prone position.  Access to the lumbar subarachnoid space
 was obtained at the level of L3-4.  20 and 18 gauge needles were used for
 access under local anesthesia, using 1% lidocaine and with aseptic
 precautions.  Average measured CSF pressure was 15.  Due to severe patient
 discomfort and low flow of CSF, only two 5 cc tubes were filled, with trace
 fluid in tube 3.

[**Hospital 3**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  83 year old man with suspicious mass in the left breast
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  core for diagnosis
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  83-year-old man presents for ultrasound-guided core biopsy of
 left breast mass.

 COMPARISON:  Comparison is made to outside printed mammogram images and
 printed static ultrasound images from from [**Hospital 28312**] [**Hospital 28313**] Hospital,
 [**Location (un) 28312**], MA, dated [**2122-7-14**].

 ULTRASOUND-GUIDED CORE BIOPSY, LEFT BREAST:  Preprocedure imaging again
 demonstrates an approximately 1.7 cm irregular hypoechoic mass in the
 retroareolar left breast.  Targeted ultrasound of the left axilla was
 performed, demonstrating several normal-appearing fatty replaced lymph nodes.

 Following explanation of the procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives,
 written informed consent was obtained with the assistance of a Russian
 interpreter.  A preprocedure timeout was performed using three patient
 identifiers.

 Using standard aseptic technique and 1% lidocaine for local anesthesia, under
 ultrasound guidance, multiple core biopsies were obtained of the hypoechoic
 mass in the retroareolar left breast using a 14-gauge coaxial spring-loaded
 biopsy device.  A percutaneous clip was subsequently placed at the site of
 biopsy under ultrasound guidance.  The needle was removed and hemostasis was
 achieved.

 Post-procedure mammogram demonstrates accurate deployment of the percutaneous
 clip in the retroareolar left mass.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.  The
 patient was discharged home with standard post-biopsy instruction.

FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Hypercalcemia and aplastic anemia.

 INTERPRETATION:  Whole body views of the skeleton were obtained, which show a
 focus of abnormally increased tracer activity, particularly on the posterior
 view, just superior to the left kidney.  In addition, a focus of increased
 tracer activity within the right foot is seen as well as at the right side of
 the cervical spine, likely relating to degenerative changes.

 SPECT images of the abdomen were then obtained.  These images showed that the
 region of increased tracer activity is superior and just posterior to the left
 kidney, in the expected location of the spleen.  On these images, a focus of
 increased tracer activity is also seen in the costochondral portion of a mid
 right thoracic rib, probably slight post-traumatic changes.

 Tracer activity is seen within the kidneys and urinary bladder, the normal route
 of tracer excretion.

 post PICC placement.  Needs repositioning.

 was present throughout the procedure.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  The patient was brought to the angiography table.  A
 pre-procedure timeout was performed.  The right upper arm was prepped and
 draped in the usual sterile fashion.  A 4-French single-lumen PICC line placed
 today from the right arm was found to be crossing the midline and terminating
 in the left subclavian vein as noted on the recent chest X-ray.  Using
 fluoroscopic guidance, the PICC line was repositioned over the wire into the
 SVC, with the tip terminating in the junction of SVC and right atrium.  A
 final fluoroscopic image was obtained. The line was flushed, StatLocked and
 hep- locked.  The line is ready for use. The patient tolerated the procedure
 without complication.

 MEDICATION:  1% lidocaine.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  83 year old male status post 14-French gastrostomy tube placement
 on [**2109-1-15**].  A CT scan performed later that evening demonstrated extensive
 subcutaneous and intraperitoneal air.  The T fasteners continued to anchor the
 anterior gastric wall to the anterior abdominal wall, but due to the presence
 of intraperitoneal air, are under a significant amount of tension.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2091**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 27**] and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 27**] was
 present throughout the procedure.

 PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS:  The patient was placed supine on the CT
 scanner, and selective upper abdominal images were obtained, demonstrating
 pneumoperitoneum.  The skin was then cleansed and draped, and under CT
 fluoroscopic guidance, a 19-gauge needle was placed just to the left of
 midline.  A 0.035 guide wire was then placed through the needle, and the
 needle was exchanged for a 4-French SOS Omni catheter.  Several 60 cc syringes
 of air were then removed under a three-way stop-cock system.  Images obtained
 through the upper abdomen following removal demonstrated a significant
 reduction in the amount of free air.  The anterior wall of the stomach is
 nearly adjacent to the anterior abdominal wall, with the degree of tension
 placed on the T fasteners significantly decreased.  A small-to-moderate amount
 of free air remains.

 COMPLICATIONS:  None.
